docs.lead_paragraph: Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, sounded a decidedly pragmatic note on President Obama's health care and energy initiatives in an interview marking the new administration's 100 days, by pointing toward compromises in which the overriding principle would be "don't make perfect the enemy of the essential."

headline.main: Top White House Aide Voices Pragmatic Approach on Health Care, Energy

docs.abstract: In an interview, the White House chief of staff uses the 100-day mark of the new administration to stress the art of compromise on key initiatives like overhauling health care and energy.
docs.snippet: In an interview, the White House chief of staff uses the 100-day mark of the new administration to stress the art of compromise on key initiatives like overhauling health care and energy.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate confirmed with a vote of 65-31 the nomination of Kathleen Sebelius as secretary of health and human services on Tuesday, filling the last vacancy in President Obama's cabinet with a seasoned politician who will take charge of the fight against swine flu.

headline.main: Senate Confirms Sebelius as Health Secretary

docs.abstract: The Senate confirmed with a vote of 65-31 the nomination of Kathleen Sebelius as secretary of health and human services on Tuesday, filling the last vacancy in President Obama's cabinet

docs.lead_paragraph: For all the uncertainty swirling around General Motors, the troubled automaker said Monday that one thing was clear: it must become drastically smaller if it hopes to remain a viable company, regardless of whether it has to file for bankruptcy.

headline.main: G.M.'s Plan Envisions a Much Smaller Automaker

docs.abstract: For all the uncertainty swirling around General Motors, the troubled automaker said Monday that one thing was clear: it must become drastically smaller if it hopes to remain a viable company, regardless of whether it has to file for bankruptcy. G.M. said it would eliminate another 21,000 factory jobs, close 13 plants, cut its vast [...]

docs.lead_paragraph: As countries look for a balance between keeping their citizens safe from the swine flu and avoiding alarm, travelers are facing two issues: personal safety and an unfriendly welcome abroad.

headline.seo: Swine Flu - What Travelers Should Know

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional Democrats sealed an agreement on a budget plan that would help President Barack Obama overhaul the health care system but allows his signature tax cut for most workers to expire after next year. The agreement, announced by Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota and the Budget Committee chairman, would prevent Senate Republicans from delaying or blocking Mr. Obama’s effort to vastly expand government-subsidized health care.

byline.original: By BILL VLASIC and NICK BUNKLEY

docs.lead_paragraph: Travel health expert Dr. Mark Gendreau addresses questions about the current swine flu outbreak and air travel. Dr. Gendreau is senior staff physician and vice chair of emergency medicine at Lahey Clinic in Burlington, Mass., and assistant professor of emergency medicine at the Tufts School of Medicine in Boston. His special interests include health issues associated with commercial air travel, including transmission of infectious diseases.

headline.main: Is It Safe to Fly During the Swine Flu Outbreak?

docs.abstract: Dr. Mark Gendreau offers advice on safe plant travel during the current swine flu outbreak.
docs.snippet: Dr. Mark Gendreau offers advice on safe plant travel during the current swine flu outbreak.
